text: In Greek mythology, Callirrhoe, Callirhoe or occasionally Kallirroi (; Ancient Greek: Καλλιρρόη meaning "beautiful flow") may refer to the following characters: * Callirrhoe (Oceanid), one of the Oceanid daughters of Oceanus and Tethys, and the mother of Geryon by Chrysaor.Hesiod, Theogony 351 * Callirhoe, wife of Peiras, son of King Argus of Argos, son of Zeus and Niobe. She was the mother of Argus, Arestorides and Triopas.Hyginus, Fabulae 145 * Callirhoe, daughter of the river god Scamander, wife of Tros,Tzetzes on Lycophron, 29Scholiast on Homer's Iliad 20.231 who refers to Hellanicus as his authority and thus, mother of Ilus, Assaracus, Ganymede, CleopatraPseudo- Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3.12.2 and possibly, Cleomestra.Dictys Cretensis, Trojan War Chronicle 4.22 * Callirhoe, daughter of Meander and consort of Car.Stephanus of Byzantium s. v. Alabanda * Callirhoe, daughter of Nestus, mother of Biston, Odomas and Edonus by Ares. * Callirhoe, a maiden who was loved by Coresus.Pausanias, Graeciae Descriptio 7.21.1 * Callirrhoe, daughter of the river-god Achelous, who betrothed her to Alcmaeon.Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3.7.6 ffPausanias, Graeciae Descriptio 8.24.8-10 * Callirhoe, daughter of Lycus, king of Libya. She fell in love with Diomedes and saved him from being sacrificed to Ares by her father. After Diomedes left Libya, she hanged herself.Plutarch, Parallela minora 23 * Callirhoe, daughter of the Boeotian Phocus.Plutarch, Amatoriae Narrationes 4 ==Notes== ==References== * Gaius Julius Hyginus, Fabulae from The Myths of Hyginus translated and edited by Mary Grant.
